title: MLB DFS Bargains: Thursday 9/26
text:
Welcome to MLB DFS Bargains. We’ll split the analysis into three groups: very cheap, mid-tier, and expensive. A greater emphasis will be placed on the lower end of the price scale.

Please note, these player picks were organized early in the day. For MLB contests, always check lineups and weather closer to game time. Rain, wind, or unexpected managerial decisions could open up additional sources of value. Be sure to keep an eye on the MLB Headlines and Injuries desk.

It’s the final Thin Thursday of 2019. Only five games are in the slate.

Scroll to continue with content Ad

DIRT CHEAP BARGAINS

Franmil Reyes – OF – Cleveland Indians (at Dylan Cease)

As is often the case, Reyes is among the top options for pure power. While he doesn’t deliver consistent day-to-day production, few hitters are likelier to hit multiple home runs. Cease has struggled to keep the ball in the yard during his first taste of the majors (1.85 HR/9). As a result, Reyes projects to hit one-third of a home run tonight.

Josh Reddick – OF – Houston Astros (at Jaime Barria)

Reddick is a very different pick. The Astros ninth hitter should be considered as a contrarian plug-in to an otherwise very popular Astros stack. Reddick figures to deliver solid, unspectacular numbers as part of the Houston onslaught. You’re hoping for a couple hits or walks with some run production tacked on. He chains well with Michael Brantley and Alex Bregman.

Seth Brown – OF – Oakland Athletics (at Felix Hernandez)

Khris Davis – OF – Oakland Athletics (at Felix Hernandez)

Story continues

King Felix is probably making his last start as a Mariner. As we’re all aware, he’s a shadow of his former self. He’s caught the homer bug (2.17 HR/9) while struggling to induce whiffs. He’s still a ground ball pitcher which works against him in this matchup against a very fly ball-oriented Athletics offense.

We missed out on an interesting matchup for Davis yesterday due to a stomach bug. He might sit again. If not, he’s showing some signs of life in September – just in time for the postseason. As for Brown, it’s shocking that he’s posted a .328/.384/.507 batting line through 73 plate appearances without hitting a home run. Earlier in the year, he slugged 37 big flies in 500 Triple-A plate appearances. His line drive and fly ball-centric approach should yield fruit tonight.

Also Consider: Jack Mayfield, Lewis Brinson, Ryan Flaherty, Robinson Cano, Pablo Reyes, Zack Collins

MID-TIER MUST PLAYS

Francisco Lindor – SS – Cleveland Indians (at Dylan Cease)

Lindor is strangely cheap for what figures to be the third-most popular stack in a thin slate. Cease has tossed a few strong outings – including against these same Indians. However, he’s had trouble with command and (of course) home runs. There’s no complicated reason to want Lindor tonight – he’s one of the top five hitters in the slate despite a mid-tier price tag. As an added bonus, Guaranteed Rate Field is power friendly. And for the cherry on top, the White Sox bullpen is exploitable.

Also Consider: Michael Brantley, Matt Chapman, Brandon Nimmo, Sean Murphy, Matt Olson, Yasiel Puig

HIGH PRICED VALUES

Zack Wheeler – SP – New York Mets (vs Marlins)

Wheeler is the only pitcher available who looks like a dollar-for-dollar value. It’s hard to judge these things in the last week of the season though. There’s a chance the Mets will cut his outing short. However, since he’s set to become a free agent soon, they don’t have much incentive to worry about his health. I’m expected a fairly typical outing. If that’s the case, he projects to deliver around seven innings with as many strikeouts versus a feeble Marlins offense.

Also Consider: Yordan Alvarez, Pete Alonso
description: Brad Johnson reviews his favorite MLB DFS bargain targets for Thursday, September 26. (Getty Images)
